text: Jules Joseph Lefebvre (Tournan-en-Brie, 14 March 1836 – Paris, 24 February 1911) was a French figure painter. Lefebvre went to the École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts in 1852. He was a pupil of Léon Cogniet. He won the prestigious Prix de Rome in 1861. Between 1855 and 1898, he exhibited 72 portraits in the Paris Salon. In 1891, he became a member of the French Académie des Beaux-Arts. He was a teacher at the Académie Julian in Paris. One of his famous students was the Scottish born landscape painter William Hart. Georges Rochegrosse, Félix Vallotton, the Americans Childe Hassam, John Henry Twachtman, John Noble Barlow, Augustus Kenderdine, and Charles A. Platt were also his pupils. He was a professor at the École des Beaux-Arts for a long time. His paintings are usually single figures of beautiful women. Among his best portraits were those of M. L. Reynaud and the Prince Imperial (1874). Among his many decorations were a first-class medal at the Paris Exhibition of 1878 and the medal of honor in 1886. He was a Commander of the Legion of Honor and a member of the Institut de France. == Gallery == Jules Lefebvre.jpg|Jules Lefebvre in his workshop Image:La Vérité, par Jules Joseph Lefebvre.jpg|La Vérité (Truth) is a painting done in 1870. It is in the Musée d'Orsay, Paris today. It is among Lefebvre's best known works. Image:Japonaise.jpg|The Japonaise (1882) Category:1836 births Category:1911 deaths Category:French painters
